RUNNING TO GOD

SWAN VIEW, PERTH • 6,859 KM

HOMETHE ROADCAMPFIREJOURNALTHE STORYCONTACT

RUNNING TO GOD

HOMETHE ROADCAMPFIREJOURNALTHE STORYCONTACT

A ROUND TRIP ACROSS THE AUSTRALIAN OUTBACK

THE ROAD

6,859.5 kilometres. 30 stops. Out across the Nullarbor to Port Lincoln, and back via the Eyre Peninsula, Esperance and Israelite Bay.

→ OUTBOUND

Swan View → Toodyay → Dowerin → Koorda → Bencubbin → Mukinbudin → Boondi Rock → Coolgardie → Norseman → Caiguna → Madura → Eucla → Border Village → Nullarbor → Mexican Hat → Ceduna → Port Lincoln

← RETURN (VIA COAST)

Port Lincoln → Coffin Bay → Colton Bakehouse → Talia Caves → Venus Bay → Penong → Cactus Beach → Point Sinclair → Port Le Hunte → Norseman → Esperance → Pink Lake →Israelite Bay → Swan View

6,859.5 KM TOTAL • 30 STOPS

HEADING EAST →

0km

SWAN VIEW

Perth, Western Australia

31.9°S 116.0°E

Packed the car at dawn. The road stretched out ahead—thousands of kilometres of unknown waiting. Left behind the familiar. Drove towards... something.

85km

TOODYAY

Avon Valley

31.6°S 116.5°E

Historic town nestled in the Avon Valley. The first taste of country WA. Rolling hills and heritage buildings.

155km

DOWERIN

Wheatbelt

31.2°S 117.0°E

Deep into wheat country now. Golden paddocks stretching to the horizon. The landscape starting to open up.

215km

KOORDA

Wheatbelt

30.8°S 117.5°E

Small farming community. The kind of place where everyone waves as you drive past.

270km

BENCUBBIN

Wheatbelt

30.8°S 117.9°E

Grain silos towering over the main street. This is the heart of WA's wheat belt.

340km

MUKINBUDIN

Wheatbelt

30.9°S 118.2°E

The edge of the wheatbelt. Beyond here, the landscape starts to change. Getting further from everything familiar.

420km

BOONDI ROCK

Outback WA

31.2°S 119.1°E

Ancient granite outcrop rising from the red earth. A sacred place. Stopped here to stretch the legs and feel the silence.

560km

COOLGARDIE

Goldfields

31.2°S 121.2°E

Ghost of the gold rush. Once home to 15,000 people chasing dreams. Now a quiet reminder that nothing lasts forever.

720km

NORSEMAN

Gateway to the Nullarbor

32.2°S 121.8°E

Last real town before the crossing. Filled the tank, checked the tyres, bought enough water for a small army. The servo owner asked where I was headed. "East," I said. He just nodded.

"The Lord himself goes before you and will be with you."

— Deuteronomy 31:8

930km

CAIGUNA ROADHOUSE

Start of the 90 Mile Straight

32.3°S 125.5°E

146.6 kilometres without a single turn coming up. The longest straight road in Australia. Fuel, coffee, deep breath.

1,090km

MADURA ROADHOUSE

Nullarbor

31.9°S 127.0°E

Perched on the edge of the Madura Pass. The views here are something else. The endless plain stretching out below.

1,180km

EUCLA

Nullarbor

31.7°S 128.9°E

Old telegraph station slowly being swallowed by sand dunes. Time moves differently out here.

1,200km

BORDER VILLAGE

WA/SA Border

31.0°S 129.0°E

Crossed into South Australia. Changed the clock forward. Somehow felt like more than just a timezone change.

1,400km

NULLARBOR ROADHOUSE

The Heart of Nowhere

31.4°S 130.9°E

Met a grey nomad couple who'd been on the road for three years. "You're not running from something," the old man said. "You're running to something. I can see it in your eyes."

"Be still and know that I am God."

— Psalm 46:10

1,500km

MEXICAN HAT

Bunda Cliffs Lookout

31.0°S 129.5°E

Named for the rock formation that looks like a sombrero. But the real attraction is the view—100-metre cliffs plunging into the Southern Ocean. Watched whales breach in the distance. Wept.

"The heavens declare the glory of God."

— Psalm 19:1

2,100km

CEDUNA

South Australia

32.1°S 133.7°E

End of the Nullarbor. Civilisation returns. A real shower, a real bed. But somehow I missed the silence already.

TURNAROUND POINT

3,430km

PORT LINCOLN

Eyre Peninsula, SA

34.7°S 135.9°E

The turnaround point. Parked the car, walked to the water, sat down. Didn't move for an hour. Somewhere on that road, I'd found what I was looking for. Or maybe it found me.

"He who began a good work in you will carry it on to completion."

— Philippians 1:6
← THE LONG WAY HOME

3,450km

COFFIN BAY

Eyre Peninsula

34.6°S 135.5°E

Famous for its oysters. Peaceful waters and rugged coastline. A quiet start to the journey home.

★

3,500km

COLTON BAKEHOUSE

The Biggest Temptation

34.3°S 135.4°E

The pies. The pastries. The smell of fresh bread. Nearly didn't leave. Some temptations are worth giving in to.

3,580km

TALIA CAVES

Eyre Peninsula

33.9°S 134.8°E

Sea caves carved by millennia of waves. The power of water against rock. The slow work of time.

3,650km

VENUS BAY

Eyre Peninsula

33.2°S 134.7°E

Pristine beaches, crystal clear water. Named by Matthew Flinders. Felt like discovering something ancient.

3,850km

PENONG

Eyre Highway

31.3°S 132.9°E

Windmill museum town. The gateway to some of Australia's best surf beaches.

3,880km

CACTUS BEACH

Point Sinclair

31.5°S 132.5°E

World-famous surf break. Even if you don't surf, the raw power of those waves is humbling.

3,900km

POINT SINCLAIR

Great Australian Bight

31.5°S 132.4°E

Remote headland jutting into the Southern Ocean. The kind of place that makes you feel very small and very alive.

3,920km

PORT LE HUNTE JETTY

Historic Jetty

31.5°S 132.4°E

Old timber jetty reaching out into the bay. Sunset here was something else. Sat on the edge with feet dangling, watching the light fade.

5,500km

NORSEMAN RETURN

Back in WA

32.2°S 121.8°E

Back at the gateway. But this time, instead of heading straight home, turned south. There was more to see.

5,700km

ESPERANCE

South Coast, WA

33.9°S 121.9°E

White sand beaches that look like they belong in the Caribbean. Lucky Bay, where kangaroos laze on the sand. A reminder that beauty often hides in unexpected places.

"The earth is the Lord's, and everything in it."

— Psalm 24:1

5,750km

PINK LAKE

Esperance

33.8°S 121.8°E

A lake that glows pink. Something about algae and salt, but the science doesn't capture the magic of it.

5,970km

ISRAELITE BAY

The Edge of Nowhere

33.6°S 123.9°E

The road turned to dirt. Then to sand. Then to almost nothing. An abandoned telegraph station. Complete isolation. Out here, at the edge of everything, the journey finally made sense.

6,859km

SWAN VIEW RETURN

Perth, Western Australia

31.9°S 116.0°E

Back where I started. But not the same person who left. 6,859.5 kilometres later, the road had done its work. The journey was over. The transformation was just beginning.

CONTINUE

GATHER AROUND THE FIRE

Every stop had a story. Some were told at roadhouses. Others came out under the stars.

CAMPFIRE TALES

RUNNING TO GOD

6,859.5 KM ROUND TRIP

A documentary journey across the Australian outback—discovering Jesus Christ on the dusty roads of the Nullarbor.

Swan View, Western Australia
